review.title: Unit contradiction versus unit propagation
review.abstract: Some aspects of the result of applying unit resolution on a CNF formula can be formalized as functions with domain a set of partial truth assignments. We are interested in two ways for computing such functions, depending on whether the result is the production of the empty clause or the assignment of a variable with a given truth value. We show that these two models can compute the same functions with formulae of polynomially related sizes, and we explain how this result is related to the CNF encoding of Boolean constraints.

sections.heading: 1.3. Contribution
sections.text: We show that any matching function can be calculated by unit contradiction if and only if it can be calculated by unit propagation, and that any family of matching functions in polynomial magnitude (then in polynomial time) can be calculated by unit contradiction if and only if it can be calculated in polynomial magnitude by unit propagation. As a logical consequence, for each family Q, if there is a polynomial upi coding for Q, there is a polynomial upac coding for Q.

sections.heading: 3. Related works
sections.text: There are at least three lines of research that relate to the investigation of the expressivity of the entity: the first is aimed at identifying the formulas that provide for a complete refutation of the contract, in the sense that it determines the complexity of the contract whether it can be refuted by a termination of the contract or not; the second is aimed at characterizing the complexity of the contract.

sections.heading: 4. Concluding remarks and perspectives
sections.text: To our knowledge, this is the first time that the resolution of units is treated as a calculation model for functions with domain partial assignments to Boolean variables. We believe that this model is suitable to characterize the inference power of unit resolution in satellite solvers. By showing that the contradiction of units has the same significance as the propagation of units, we offer a theoretical insight into the field of coding constraint satisfaction problems in cnf for their solution thanks to satellite solvers. The underlying scientific problem is nothing less than determining the scope of application of satellite solvers: What problems can reasonably be solved by satellite solvers, what not and why? We are currently working on the characterization of matching functions that can be efficiently calculated by unit resolution, and therefore on the constraints for which there are polynomic upi and upac encodings. The next step will consist of checking the booleum for a general method to match the resolution in algorithms.
